review_title: Working at Prestera has been an amazing experience.
job_title: Health and Wellness Specialist in Charleston, WV
pros: Learn something new everyday and getting to know new people
cons: Not enough training in one area

pros: Good boss and nice coworkers
cons: Salary, caseload # (60-80 consumers), long intake process, not enough time for documentation, scheduling sucks

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker in Huntington, WV
pros: There are no Pros for this company other than helping patients in need.
cons: First, they hire unlicensed individuals because they are a behavioral health agency and get away with it. They do not pay licensed or unlicensed employees a fair or competitive wage. The benefits are poor, insurance is expensive with a high deductible. Annual salary increases are a joke. I would advise anyone wanting to work for them to run. It isn't even a good first job out of college. Employers are paying double what Prestera pays for the same position. The management is horrible. The CEO, CFO, and Clinical director make a large salary for a non-profit and the employees are paid nothing. This is a top-down company. The patients suffer because there isn't enough licensed therapist as most aren't licensed. The staff turnover rate is so bad patients constantly get shifted from therapist to therapist which isn't beneficial to clients. They need to stop paying the handful of administrative staff an inflated salary, management who is handpicked and unqualified and pay case managers, therapist, and direct care staff a decent salary.

pros: Gained vital experience Location was small and close knit
cons: PAY Employees at other locations All of upper management

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Huntington, WV

pros: Benefits, overtime, management, work moral, no mandating
cons: Pay, hiring process, annual increases.

job_title: Behavior Support Professional in Charleston, WV
pros: They have recurring time off for sick and vacation. You also get holidays off.
cons: They pay less than any other company. They also now have you clock in and out. You must work 8 to 5, plus attend all of your evening meetings. If you have to drive an hour towards your home for a meeting one evening, you have to drive an hour back to the office to clock out and then you can drive an hour back home. They are managed care. Due to the low pay, they do not have many quality staff which results in the clients not receiving the care and support they need. Their sick leave policy is one that if you total you car on the way to work, you may be written up or terminated. The company focuses on punishment, not reward.

review_title: Helping people but they over work you and don't pay you enough.
pros: The clients, that really is the only thing that kept me there.
cons: Management, pay, over worked, no one is on the same page. Micromanaged. Un equal punishment among staff.

job_title: Children Service Worker in Huntington, WV
pros: The hourly pay was not bad
cons: The schedule was always messed up

review_title: This is a challenging, yet rewarding job!
pros: Therapist salaries have finally been elevated to something closer to a living-wage (in this area), we have slightly better healthy insurance than the Affordable Healthcare Act options, but the benefits received from helping others (seeing the success stories) are the most worthwhile part of the job!  The company really does value the client's best interests, so we do all we can to advocate for mental-health...
cons:
However, clinicians have very little time to complete all of the paperwork required, with some unrealistic demands handed down from administrators that lack a complete understanding of the difficulties we face.  When an emphasis is placed on assessments, the extensive documentation-time takes away from the other direct clinical services we can provide to clients (like group/individual counseling/therapy).

Also, having to find our own coverage can be a challenge sometimes if we have to call off work.  Sometimes, the lack of staff available to cover prevents us from taking the vacation time we have earned.  When we are short-staffed, everyone suffers (staff & clients).

job_title: Behavioral Rehabilitation Specialist in Charleston, WV
pros: Some of the staff members are excellent. The clients are amazing. It really isn't a hard job (physically). I feel as though (contrary to many other reviews), management actually cares about their employees, and residents. It is an extremely rewarding job. Many of the employees who have been here for longer than a few years will tell you that they are not in the mental health field for the money.
cons:
The pay is horrendous. Most sites start out at minimum wage. For a job as serious as dealing with a client's life (i.e. taking care of AMAP duties), you would think it would pay at least slightly above minimum wage. 

Even though it is an extremely rewarding job, it can be insanely stressful. There really isn't any physical work in being a BRS. Instead, it's mostly mental. The hardest part of the job dealing with conflicts (which are bound to happen at some point, especially since there are eight clients living together).

review_title: Prestera is a great place to lean and grow!!!
pros: Excellent opportunity to learn and grow both professionally and personally in the largest community mental health center in West Virginia. Continuing education and training available to those who want to continue professional learning. A vast range of job opportunities to fit most individuals who want to work with particular populations (Ex: Children, Adolescents, Adults, In home, School based and office structure), which allows flexibility in deciding what fits best for one professionally.
cons: Low pay compared to private industry and lack of support through upper management.

review_title: Work for the people, not the pay.
job_title: Behavioral Rehabilitation Specialist in Huntington, WV
pros: Friendly co-workers, you make a difference in the lives of people who typically have no one else, and you get the satisfaction of knowing that what you do actually means something and changes lives.
cons: Low pay, you pay for benefits. no real incentives to stay at Prestera anymore. Policy is always changing in one way or another. You're required to have 75 hours minimum of client interaction, though when you transport clients you can only document per mile, not per minute. Which turns what could be a 2 hour drive that you can document on into 10 minutes which tends to make keeping reports honest an impossible task..

pros: Working with the consumers is usually a joy. Sometimes there are stressful days and nights.
cons: Most of the staff are team players. We have to be consistent and united in enforcing the rules and not show favoritism.  Unfortunately there are staff that let some consumers get away with not following the rules. Some supervisors are not consistent in helping staff with problems either. Some supervisors play favorites with certain staff and contradict themselves.

review_title: No path for advancement, poor salary and benefits
pros: The clients and some co-workers are the only saving grace this company has. If you like to help people, and care for little else, this may just be the job for you. If that's the case, however, you better have a financial backup plan.
cons:
Poor salary. A couple of years before I started, the company instituted a "pay freeze" for my department, wherein no yearly raises were allowed.
The department I worked in had no path for advancement. Once you are there, you're there.
The health insurance offered did not cover anything. Leaving me with $400 in bills for two Urgent Care visits due to the Flu, and also did not cover any medical bills from a broken arm.

review_title: worked overtime everyday to keep up with documentation without compensation or acknowledgement
pros: co workers are fantastic, free parking
cons: no training, expected to fraud medicaid, long hours with no OT pay, no management support, treated patients poorly

review_title: Only been here for 7 months so far I really like it
pros: Easy, interesting and fun. Learn alot from the clients and the other staff. Everyone seems to get along and there is a lot of support from each other
cons: Need more staff for all the homes so that staff are not spread too thin and have to work so much overtime

pros: Great staff, most are easy to get along with and will answer any questions.
cons: High employee turnover right, Prestera needs to increase pay to encourage staff to stay longer.  Communication between upper management and staff needs work.

pros: The best reasons are the patients, thats what make it all worth wild. There are some decicated people who work for prestera and putting the patient first and taking care of their needs is what important!
cons: Charleston is still considered a step child to the Huntington office if things are not done like they are in Huntington then its not done right.

pros: Some of the people there still try to act like they care.
cons: Nobody from the CEO to the directors really care, they just go through the motions, unless you're upper level you don't get paid worth your time at all. Nurses make the LOWEST in the state, direct care givers work on practically slave wages, the employees have no power either because all it takes is a client making something up and they HAVE to believe them over you.
